content:
Art. 4.100. 
Contribution to the debts and expenses of the succession 
The co-heirs contribute amongst themselves to the payment of the debts and expenses of the succession, each in the proportion of what he or she takes into it.
A co-heir who, by the effect of a mortgage, has paid more than his share of the debt of the succession, has recourse against the other co-heirs only for the share which each of them must personally bear, even in the case where the co-heir who has paid the debt has been subrogated to the rights of the creditors, without prejudice however to the rights of a co-heir who, by the effect of the benefit of the inventory, has retained the right to claim payment of his personal claim, like any other creditor.
In the event of the insolvency of one of the co-heirs, his or her share of the mortgage debt is distributed proportionally to all the others.
If the co-heirs share the succession in the state in which it is and an immovable encumbered by a mortgage is attributed to one of them who will have to bear alone the burden of the annuity or the debt guaranteed by the mortgage, the encumbered immovable is valued after deduction of the capital of the annuity or of the debt.
The heir to whose lot the property falls remains solely responsible for servicing the annuity or paying the debt, and must guarantee this to his coheirs.
